contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox lake | lake_name = Naknek Lake | image_lake = Brown bear Brooks Camp.jpg | caption_lake = | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Lake and Peninsula Borough, Alaska|Lake and Peninsula Borough]] and [[Bristol Bay Borough, Alaska|Bristol Bay Borough]], [[Alaska]] | coords = {{Coord|58|38|11|N|155|56|27|W|region:US-AK_type:waterbody_scale:500000|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = | outflow = [[Naknek River]] | catchment = | basin_countries = United States | length = {{convert|64|km|mi|abbr=on}} | width = {{convert|13|km|mi|abbr=on}} | area = | depth = | max-depth = | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = | cities = }} '''Naknek Lake''' is a [[lake]] in southern [[Alaska]], near the base of the [[Alaska Peninsula]]. The lake is {{convert|64|km|mi|abbr=on}} long and 5–13 km (3–8 miles) wide. The lake drains west into [[Bristol Bay]] through the [[Naknek River]]. [[Image:AKMap-doton-KingSalmon.PNG|right|Location of King Salmon, Alaska]] The earliest Russian explorer reported the lake's name as ''Naknek'', but a later one said its name was "Akulogak". [[Ivan Petrof (explorer)|Ivan Petrof]] named the lake Lake Walker, for [[Francis Amasa Walker]], Superintendent of the 1880 United States census. The lake is famous for its [[sport fishing]]. [[Brooks Camp]] is located on the lake's shore; [[brown bear]]s may be viewed catching [[salmon]] while standing in a [[waterfall]]. [[Category:Lakes of Alaska]] [[Category:Landforms of Bristol Bay Borough, Alaska]] [[Category:Landforms of Lake and Peninsula Borough, Alaska]] [[Category:Visitor attractions in Bristol Bay Borough, Alaska]] [[Category:Visitor attractions in Lake and Peninsula Borough, Alaska]] {{LakeandPeninsulaAK-geo-stub}} {{BristolBayAK-geo-stub}}
